questions.text: 1. In which of the following structures will the following epithelium be seen?
questions.solution:
The epithelium shown in the above image can be found in the ureter.

The ureter is lined by transitional epithelium (also called urothelium), similar to the urinary bladder. This specialized epithelium allows stretching, which is crucial as the urine passes through. The presence of transitional epithelium is characteristic of structures in the urinary system, such as the ureters, bladder, and part of the urethra. In the relaxed state, the superficial cells appear cuboidal and protrude outward, with occasional binucleate cells observed within this layer.

Given below is a cross-section of the ureter showing the transitional epithelium and the layer of smooth muscle.



Other options:

Option A: Gall bladder: The gall bladder is lined by simple columnar epithelium, which facilitates the absorption of water and electrolytes from bile.



Option B: Trachea: The trachea is lined by pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium with goblet cells, which helps trap and remove particles from the respiratory tract.



Option D: Duodenum: The duodenum is lined by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells, aiding in digestion and nutrient absorption.

questions.text: 2. A patient presents with carcinoma near the anal opening. Which among the following lymph nodes are most likely to be involved first?
questions.solution:
In a patient with carcinoma near the anal opening, superficial inguinal lymph nodes are most likely to be involved first.

The tumor in the given clinical scenario is located near the anal opening, which means that it lies below the pectinate line. Lesions below this line typically drain lymph to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, making them the most likely site for metastasis.

The anal canal measures approximately 3.8 cm in length and extends from the anorectal junction to the anus. It is divided into three parts:

* The upper mucosal part is 15 mm long, is endodermal in origin, and contains the anal columns and anal sinuses. The pectinate line marks the junction between the upper mucosal part and the middle transitional zone.

* The middle transitional zone is 15 mm long, is also lined by mucous membrane, and is ectodermal in origin. The lower boundary of this part often appears whitish and is referred to as the white line of Hilton.

* The lowest cutaneous part is 8 mm long, is lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium, and contains sebaceous glands.

Lymphatic drainage from the region above the pectinate line is directed to the internal iliac lymph nodes (option B), whereas drainage from the region below this line is directed to the medial group of superficial inguinal lymph nodes. The pectinate line serves as the watershed line of the anal canal.



Pearl PM2214: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING
Para - aortic lymph nodes Ovaries /Testis
External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis


 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e

Pearl PM1265: Features of anal canal above and below pectinate line

Below Pectinate line

Arterial supply

Inferior rectal  artery

Venous drainage

Systemic: Inferior rectal vein

Lymphatic drainage

Nerve supply

Physiology

Sensation quickly diminishes

Sensitive to pain

Cancer

Varices

External hemorrhoids, Painful

questions.text: 3. The image shows a congenital cardiac defect. Abnormal development of which arch artery leads to this defect?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th aortic arch.

Usually, in term infants, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close results in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

PDA usually presents with a hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

In a majority of cases, PDA closes spontaneously. If spontaneous closure fails to occur, COX inhibitors like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be used. Surgical ligation is indicated in case of contraindications to medical management or failure of the same.

Other options

Option A: The 4th right aortic arch gives rise to the proximal part of the right subclavian artery. 

Option B: The 4th left aortic arch gives rise to the arch of the aorta. Defects involving the 4th left aortic arch could cause a variety of aortic arch anomalies, such as interruption of the aortic arch, but not PDA.

Option C: The 6th right aortic arch forms the proximal part of the right pulmonary artery.

Pearl PM0894: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.



The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text: 4. An intern was assisting a delivery, and the resident asked the intern to comment on the umbilical cord. What is the normal vasculature of the umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
The normal umbilical cord contains two umbilical arteries with one large vein.

A normal umbilical cord consists of Wharton's jelly, which is a mesodermal connective tissue, and is covered by the amnion. It contains the following structures:

* 1 umbilical vein that carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the foetus,

* 2 umbilical arteries  that carry deoxygenated blood from the foetus to the placenta,

* Remnants of the yolk sac and allantois.

Around 1 in 200 newborns have only a single umbilical artery. These infants have increased chances of having cardiac and other vascular defects.

The following shows the normal vasculature of the umbilical cord:

questions.text: 5. During resection of the submandibular gland, the following structure was encountered. Identify the same.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the lingual nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve.

Nerves at risk for injury during removal of the submandibular gland include:

* Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve

* Lingual nerve

* Hypoglossal nerve

During submandibular gland dissection, the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle serves as an important landmark. Retracting this border anteriorly exposes the deep lobe of the gland, which is then pulled downward while noting its connection to the lingual nerve via parasympathetic secretomotor fibers.

The hyoglossus muscle also acts as a key landmark in this region. Its superficial surface is related to the lingual nerve, the hypoglossal nerve (option A), and the submandibular gland. The lingual nerve lies superior to the deep part of the gland, whereas the hypoglossal nerve lies inferior, running deep within the submandibular capsule and needing preservation during intracapsular dissection.

The image below illustrates the relationship of the lingual nerve and the hypoglossal nerve with the hyoglossus muscle:



Complications of submandibular gland resection:

* Haematoma

* Wound infection

* Marginal mandibular nerve injury

* Lingual nerve injury

* Hypoglossal nerve injury

* Transection of the nerve to the mylohyoid muscle producing submental skin anaesthesia

Other options:

Option B: The marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve runs in the superficial fascia, typically crossing the facial vessels near the lower border of the mandible, and must be preserved during surgery to avoid injury.

Option D: The facial artery passes deep to the posterior belly of the digastric and stylohyoid muscles and then either traverses through or superficially over the submandibular gland to reach the anterior border of the mandible.

Pearl PM1689: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

* Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.

* Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

Type of Salivary gland

questions.text: 6. Which of the following nerves does not pass through foramen marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is the jugular foramen. The nerve that does not pass through it is the Hypoglossal nerve.

The hypoglossal nerve passes via the hypoglossal canal.

The structures passing through the jugular foramen are as follows:

* Inferior petrosal sinus

* Meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery

* Glossopharyngeal Nerve - IX (option B)

* Vagus Nerve - X (option A)

* Spinal Accessory Nerve - XI (option D)

* Sigmoid Sinus continuing as the internal jugular vein

* Middle meningeal branch of the occipital artery

    • Apical ligament and tip of dens

  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: 7. A patient presents with pain on the lateral side of the thigh. The doctor diagnosed him with meralgia paresthetica. Identify the nerve affected?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is a neuropathic pain syndrome affecting the anterolateral thigh due to compression or entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN), which is marked as "3" in the given image.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury, especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament, just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension, which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve.

Patients may develop meralgia paresthetica as a complication of inguinal hernia repair. The initial management of this nerve entrapment involves conservative measures like rest, application of ice, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), physical therapy, and local injections of corticosteroids and anesthetics. If symptoms persist, treatment may progress to medications like gabapentin or its analogues.

Other nerves marked in the image:

Marking Nerve
1 Illiohypogastric nerve
2 Genitofemoral nerve
4 Femoral nerve


Pearl PM1236: Lumbar Plexus

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve. 

The following table shows the branches of the lumbar plexus, their root value, muscles innervated, and cutaneous branches:

questions.text: 8. What is the nerve supply to the following labelled muscles?

choices.text: a - Nerve to mylohyoid, b -Facial nerve
a - Hypoglossal nerve, b - Ansa cervicalis
a - Mandibular nerve,  b - Facial nerve
a - Accessory nerve, b - Mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
The structures marked in the given image are the anterior (a) and posterior (b) bellies of the Digastric muscle. The anterior belly (a) is supplied by the nerve to the mylohyoid, and the posterior belly (b) is supplied by the facial nerve.

The digastric muscle is a hybrid muscle, i.e., it is supplied by two different nerves with different root values. The digastric muscle has two bellies, anterior and posterior. The posterior belly arises from the mastoid notch on the temporal bone and slopes downward and forward. The anterior belly arises from the digastric fossa on the inner surface of the mandible, which slopes downward and backward. The two bellies connect at the intermediate tendon. The intermediate tendon passes through a connective tissue loop attached to the hyoid bone.

Other hybrid muscles of the head and neck include:

* Sternocleidomastoid (SCM): Motor supply is by the spinal accessory nerve, and proprioception is by the ventral rami of cervical nerves (C2, C3).

* Trapezius: Motor supply is by the spinal accessory nerve, and proprioception is by the ventral rami of cervical nerves (C3, C4).

questions.text: 9. Which of the following is not a functional component of the marked nerve in the given image?
questions.solution:
The nerve marked in the image is the Vagus nerve (X). General Somatic Efferent is not its functional component.

The Vagus nerve (X) exits the skull through the jugular foramen. In the neck, it descends within a carotid sheath between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.

The following are the functional components of the Vagus (X) nerve:

* Sensory from the ear: General Somatic Afferent (option C)

* Sensory from pharynx/larynx: General Visceral Afferent (option D)

* Taste from the root of tongue and the epiglottis: Special Visceral Afferent

* Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen: General Visceral Efferent (option B)

* Motor to 4th/6th arch derivatives: Special Visceral Efferent (branchial efferent/branchiomotor)



Pearl PM2242: Functional components of cranial nerves

Functional components of cranial nerves 
Oculomotor: CN-3
  • Extraocular skeletal muscles – GSE
  • Preganglionic fibres to ciliary ganglion - GVE
Trochlear: CN-4
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (SO)- GSE
Trigeminal: CN-5
  • Sensation from the face - GSA
  • Motor to 1st arch - Br E (SVE)
Abducent: CN-6
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (lateral rectus)- GSE
Facial: CN-7
  • General sensory from ear - GSA
  • Special (taste) sensation - Br A
  • Motor to 2nd arch - Br E
  • Parasympathetic to submandibular and pterygopalatine ganglia - GVE
Vestibulocochlear: CN-8
  • Hearing/balance - SSA
Glossopharyngeal: CN-9
  • Sensory from pharynx/tongue – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • General sensation from ear – GSA
  • Parasympathetic to otic ganglion - GVE
  • Motor to 3rd arch - Br E
Vagus: CN-10
  • Sensory from ear - GSA
  • Sensory from pharynx/larynx – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen - GVE
  • Motor to 4th/6th arch - Br E
Accessory: CN-11
  • Motor to 6th arch (through vagus) - Br E
  • Motor to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius - GSE
Hypoglossal: CN-12
  • Motor to lingual muscles – GSE


abbr.

A - afferent , E - efferent , Br - Branchial (word special (derived from branchial arches) can also be used instead of branchial, but due to confusion with special sensory (carrying special senses) its better avoided), V - Visceral, G - General, CN - cranial nerve,  SO - superior oblique muscle.

questions.text: 10. A 19-year-old athlete was training. While doing the hyperextension exercises, he felt a sharp pain in the shoulders. His trainer suspected avulsion of the long head of the triceps. From which site was the muscle detached?
questions.solution:
The long head of the triceps is attached to the Infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

Triceps form the extensor compartment of the upper arm. It has three heads- long, lateral and medial. The long head arises by a flattened tendon from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula. Its muscular fibres join the lateral head and the medial head to form a common tendon.

The lateral head arises from the posterior surface of the humeral shaft and the lateral intermuscular septum. The medial head, which is overlapped posteriorly by the lateral and long heads, is attached to the entire posterior surface of the humeral shaft, the medial border of the humerus, the medial intermuscular septum, and the lower part of the lateral intermuscular septum.

The fibres insert into the olecranon process of the ulna. Triceps is innervated by branches from the radial nerve. The blood supply is derived mainly from the profunda brachii artery and the superior ulnar collateral artery, with an accessory supply from the posterior circumflex humeral artery.
